user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 msecs)
{
    struct timespec                     ts;
    int                                 result;
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    /*
     ** Compute an absolute time for the delay
     */
    OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime(msecs, &ts);

    if (sem_timedwait(&impl->id, &ts) == 0)
    {
        result = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else if (errno == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        result = OS_SEM_TIMEOUT;
    }
    else
    {
        /* unspecified failure */
        result = OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return result;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t id;
} OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t
...
OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_MAX_COUNT_SEMAPHORES]
...
void OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime(uint32 msecs, struct timespec *tm)
{
    clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, tm);

    /* add the delay to the current time */
    tm->tv_sec += (time_t)(msecs / 1000);
    /* convert residue ( msecs )  to nanoseconds */
    tm->tv_nsec += (msecs % 1000) * 1000000L;

    if (tm->tv_nsec >= 1000000000L)
    {
        tm->tv_nsec -= 1000000000L;
        tm->tv_sec++;
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No parameter of OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl is modified in the shown code. Reasoning:
- The function parameters are: const OS_object_token_t *token and uint32 msecs. There are no assignments to token or msecs anywhere in the function body.
- The use impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(..., *token) passes *token to a macro that takes the address of that argument (&(tok)) — with *token this becomes &(*token) which is the original token pointer; this takes the address but does not modify the token parameter itself. OS_ObjectIndexFromToken takes a const pointer and only reads token->obj_idx.
- OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime receives msecs by value (a copy) and modifies the timespec pointed to by &ts; modifying an object referred to by a pointer parameter (tm) is permitted by the rule, and ts is a local variable, not a function parameter.
- sem_timedwait(&impl->id, &ts) operates on the semaphore and the local timespec; it does not modify the function parameters.
- No other code fragments assign to or otherwise alter the value of any function parameter.
Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the provided code.
